bioghist.p: Philip Pearsall Carpenter (1819-1877) in early life was an English minister, educator, philanthropist and reformer with a special interest in natural history as a hobby. Later he became a specialist in the study of mollusks and wrote two monographic works which were published, shorter papers, and an unpublished monumental work on Chitons. He visited the United States, where he became associated with the California Academy of Sciences in 1857 and studied West Coast shells. He returned to England for a short time and in 1865 moved to Montreal. His collections that were not included in the British Museum, the Smithsonian or the California Academy of Sciences were given to Magill University in Montreal.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of seven letters sent to P.P. Carpenter between 1875 and 1876 from William H. Baily, L. Pourtales, and Edgar A. Smith. Letters discuss specimens of fossil Chitons.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia: Chiton manuscript (collection 409) and unidentified notes and manuscript (probably P.P. Carpenter).
